Title.evidence: Goal Attainment Scaling-Based Rehabilitation in Knee Arthroplasty: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: This single-center randomised controlled trial included patients younger than 65 years, working outside the home, and scheduled for unicompartmental or total KA.

Participants.evidence: patients younger than 65 years, working outside the home, and scheduled for unicompartmental or total KA. The study was conducted at a regional teaching hospital.

Intervention.evidence: GAS-based rehabilitation involved preoperative development of personal activity goals with a physiotherapist, while standard rehabilitation consisted of regular outpatient physiotherapy.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate whether goal attainment scaling (GAS)-based rehabilitation improves satisfaction with postoperative activities in patients undergoing knee arthroplasty (KA) compared to standard rehabilitation.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was satisfaction with activities of daily living, work, and leisure-time activities, measured using visual analogue scales (VAS) at 1 year postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using block randomisation with allocation concealment via sequentially numbered opaque envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Participants, researchers, and physiotherapists were unblinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 120 patients were randomised 1:1 to either GAS-based rehabilitation or standard rehabilitation.

Number_Analysed.evidence: 53 in the GAS group and 58 in the control group analysed using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Satisfaction with work activities was significantly higher in the GAS group (β = 10.7 points, 98% CI = 2.0 to 19.4 points).
